title-group.article-title: Neuer Totemismus? Überlegungen zur Genese und Semantik moderner Tierbestattung

abstract.p: The article investigates social and cultural conditions of the institutionalization of pet cemeteries in modern Western societies. After a brief description of their characteristics and their historical origins, such as urbanization, it is shown that (a) the trend of institutionalization is in the long run sociostructurally based on changes of the private lifeworld—especially of the family —, and on processes of individualization in society. In a further step (b), the increasing relevance of the pets' death is related to the contemporary conditions of the dying of human beings, particularly to the so-called "rarely dying". In regard to the cultural context (c), it is argued that pet burials may be considered as a ritual expression of a new totemism, which is grounded on the zoosemantics of the "betwixt-and-between"-position of the athropomorphically experienced pet. Finally, the corresponding tendency to a "numinosic" view of the pet animal is briefly exemplified with two different types of modern pet graves.
